G.L. c. 209B.proposition: The minor child, Emily Turner, has resided in Massachusetts for more than six months prior to the filing of this Complaint, and this Court has continuing and exclusive jurisdiction regarding custody and parenting time pursuant to the Massachusetts child custody jurisdiction statutes and the principles reflected in the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement Act (UCCJEA), G.L. c. 209B.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a prior custody or parenting-time judgment may be modified upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) that modification is necessary to serve the present best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The “best interests of the child” is the paramount consideration in any custody or parenting-time determination or modification.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 842\u201.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a prior custody or parenting-time judgment may be modified upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) that modification is necessary to serve the present best interests of the child.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 842\u201.support_reasoning: This opinion is not a modification case and does not articulate the standard for modifying an existing custody or parenting-time judgment. It notes, in dicta, that G.L. c. 209C, § 20 requires a ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ for modification, but it neither applies a two-prong test nor states that modification must also be necessary to serve the present best interests of the child. The case instead addresses initial custody determinations under the ‘best interests of the child’ standard in G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), and expressly declines to consider the father’s argument that the modification standard should govern.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 842\u201.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 209C, § 20, gives the Probate Court jurisdiction to modify an existing judgment for support, custody, or visitation. Such a modification should be made only if ‘a substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child has occurred.’ Id. … We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a).”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899, 899–900 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a prior custody or parenting-time judgment may be modified upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) that modification is necessary to serve the present best interests of the child.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion addresses the substantive standard for making an initial custody award and emphasizes that the governing principle is the welfare/best interests of the child. It does not discuss modification of a prior custody or parenting-time judgment, nor does it articulate any requirement of a material and substantial change in circumstances as a precondition to modifying an existing order. Thus, it cannot be cited as authority for the specific two-part modification standard described in the proposition.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.proposition: The “best interests of the child” is the paramount consideration in any custody or parenting-time determination or modification.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the need for explicit findings about domestic violence and its effects on the child in custody decisions, and on compliance with statutory requirements for findings when there is a 209A order. In the quoted portion, the court does not articulate the general standard that the best interests of the child are the paramount consideration in custody or parenting-time determinations or modifications; that principle is assumed but not expressly stated or developed as a holding here. Thus, this case is not strong authority for that specific proposition.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.relevant_excerpt: Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. The very frequency of domestic violence in disputes about child custody may have the effect of inuring courts to it and thus minimizing its significance. Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.proposition: The “best interests of the child” is the paramount consideration in any custody or parenting-time determination or modification.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely frames the post-unfitness question as which placement is in the child’s best interests and treats that standard as the controlling, dispositive consideration in resolving the custody/adoption placement dispute. The court emphasizes that the “central question” after a finding of unfitness is the child’s best interests, and it repeatedly analyzes all competing plans solely through that lens, indicating that best interests is the paramount standard in such custody/placement determinations.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’ … Presented with more than one potential adoption placement, the judge’s task is to determine which plan will serve the best interests of the child, not to afford any particular weight to either plan.”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 551\u2.proposition: Parenting-time orders are subject to revision where the current arrangement no longer reflects the realities of the parties’ circumstances or the developmental needs and best interests of the child.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 551\u2.support_reasoning: The quoted concurrence focuses on statutory interpretation of the paternity statute and the limits on a judge’s authority to order a custodial parent to relocate back to Massachusetts. It discusses how custody and visitation should be fashioned after paternity is established and emphasizes stability and respect for the custodial parent’s relocation, but it does not address modification standards for existing parenting‑time orders when circumstances or a child’s developmental needs change. The proposition about revision of parenting‑time orders over time therefore is not actually grounded in this opinion.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 551\u2.relevant_excerpt: “After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003) (‘If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement…’).”}

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 270–271 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Parenting-time orders are subject to revision where the current arrangement no longer reflects the realities of the parties’ circumstances or the developmental needs and best interests of the child.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with modification of *custody* under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and a parent’s request to *relocate* under § 30, not with routine revision of parenting-time/visitation schedules based on evolving circumstances or developmental needs. The court emphasizes that a custody modification requires a material and substantial change in circumstances and that removal decisions must consider the child’s best interests and the custodial parent’s ‘real advantage,’ but it does not discuss revising parenting-time orders where the schedule no longer reflects current realities or developmental stages. Thus it does not clearly support the specific proposition about parenting-time orders being revisable on that basis.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 (‘the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

Adoption of Arthur, 34 Mass. App. Ct. 91.raw_text: Adoption of Arthur, 34 Mass. App. Ct. 914, 915 (1993)
Adoption of Arthur, 34 Mass. App. Ct. 91.proposition: The minor child is now of sufficient age and maturity to express her wishes regarding the amount of time she spends with each parent, and her views are entitled to due weight in assessing her best interests.
Adoption of Arthur, 34 Mass. App. Ct. 91.support_reasoning: The case involves a 14‑year‑old child whose preference regarding adoption was elicited in camera and then considered by the judge. The Appeals Court expressly holds that the judge acted within his discretion in giving weight to Arthur’s expressed desire to be adopted. While the opinion does not discuss a specific age threshold or the exact amount of time with each parent, it clearly recognizes that a mature minor’s views are entitled to weight in assessing best interests, which is consistent with the general proposition cited.
Adoption of Arthur, 34 Mass. App. Ct. 91.relevant_excerpt: “We think, therefore, that the judge committed no error of law and acted within his sound discretion in giving weight to Arthur’s expressed desire to be adopted. Nor was there any violation of the father’s rights under the confrontation clause of either the Federal or State Constitution, as the father contends, because the proceedings were civil in nature.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u20.proposition: The child’s expressed wishes are reasonable, age‑appropriate, and consistent with the developmental benefits of having frequent and meaningful contact with both parents where safe and appropriate.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the best‑interests standard for relocation in a joint physical custody context and the importance of preserving frequent and continued contact with both parents. It does not discuss, evaluate, or give any legal significance to a child’s expressed wishes, nor does it address whether those wishes are reasonable or developmentally appropriate. The claimed proposition about the child’s expressed wishes is therefore not supported by this case.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u20.relevant_excerpt: “Shared physical custody contemplates that ‘a child shall have periods of residing with and being under the supervision of each parent . . . [assuring] . . . frequent and continued contact with both parents.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31. … Where physical custody is shared and neither parent has a clear majority of custodial responsibility, the child’s interests will typically ‘favor protection of the child’s relationships with both parents because both are, in a real sense, primary to the child’s development.’”

Morales v. Morales, 464 Mass. 507, 512\u.proposition: These changed circumstances are continuing, not temporary, and they directly impact the best‑interests analysis with respect to physical custody, parenting time, and the allocation of parental responsibilities.
Morales v. Morales, 464 Mass. 507, 512\u.support_reasoning: The case deals exclusively with modification of a child support order and the proper standard (material and substantial change vs. inconsistency with the Child Support Guidelines). It does not address physical custody, parenting time, allocation of parental responsibilities, or whether changed circumstances must be continuing rather than temporary in that context. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition stated, which concerns best‑interests analysis for physical custody and parenting time, not child support modification.
Morales v. Morales, 464 Mass. 507, 512\u.relevant_excerpt: “Prior to its amendment in 1993 … § 28 provided that the material and substantial change standard was the correct standard for determining whether to modify a custody judgment or a child support order. … The 1993 amendment to § 28 clearly separated custody determinations from child support orders, applying the material and substantial change standard to modifications of custody orders and the inconsistency standard to modifications of child support orders.”
